intro: Volvulus marginatus, commonly known as the marginated volvulus, is a species of flowering plant native to certain regions of Africa. It belongs to the family Acanthaceae and is characterized by its distinctive, often colorful foliage. The plant typically features opposite leaves with serrated edges, and its flowers are usually small and clustered in whorls. It thrives in moist, well-drained soils and is often found in woodland or streamside habitats. Due to its ornamental value, it is sometimes cultivated in gardens, though it can be invasive in certain environments.
